user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_unmap:
```c
void metal_dma_unmap(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg,
		  int nents)
{
	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/*If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);

	if (!dev || !dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap || !sg)
		return;
	dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg, nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (!dev || !dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap || !sg)
		return;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment only performs NULL checks on existing pointer parameters. MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 concerns whether pointer types should be declared to point to const-qualified types when the pointed-to objects are not modified. The shown code fragment does not declare the pointers and does not by itself violate the rule. (If, in the broader context, dev or sg are never modified and could be declared as const pointers, then the function signature should use const-qualified pointer types — that would be a violation of 8.13 in the current code.)
